review: I already have a Roku and AppleTV and was surprised that the Amazon Fire TV beats them both. Why?1. Obviously the voice-search (and you can also search via keyboard if you wish, but it's a pain).2. Easy and comfortable access to your Amazon movies/music3. The interface is really smooth, and I love that I can look at IMDB immediately after watching a movie (which I used to do on a laptop/tablet manually).4. The apps are fun.5. Non proprietary- you can watch Amazon Prime or Netflix. So it still makes sense if you don't have Amazon Prime, although it's far better if you have it.Downsides?1. Many of the games require the overpriced game controller, which stinks. Some use the remote that comes with it.2. I had some initial problems with the remote... took some digging to figure out how to reconnect it (after ruling out batteries don't work). The problem is that there's no indicator that tells you the remote is even functioning or has batteries.It's a little more difficult to get into my Netflix collection, but it's there.3. Can't figure out how to stream my non-Amazon movies sitting on my Mac laptop. Hopefully an app solves that.Roku has some advantages with the version that comes with headphones attached to the remote, although I use this feature less than I expected. AppleTV, while an initial bold leader, hasn't evolved and only makes sense to access your Apple purchases. It's a lot of work to convert a Mac desktop movie to play on AppleTV.

review: My original review was a Five star until 6 months later when I was having trouble viewing Netflix. I noticed that while viewing my Netflix movies there was sporadic freezing; frame freeze with sound still playing. I went through all the items on Amazon's help link to correct the issue which didn't work.My next step was to contact tech support. After talking to three different tech support individuals and running through more procedures to correct the issue, it still didn't work. Amazon's conclusion was that it was my router, that it didn't put out a strong enough signal for the Netflix app for this devise. I have two TV's that use the same router, one in the living-room and the other in the bedroom next to the router. The tv in the bedroom has no problem with the Netflix app..Here I'm left with having to decide whether I need to purchase another router or try another devise, Amazon would not refund or replace this devise after 6 months.So I purchased a Sony Blu-ray player with the same apps and installed it. Guess what it works great! The freeze frame is gone and I can watch my Netflix again.Because I felt that I can't use the Amazon Five TV because of the problem mentioned above, I should be entitled to a refund or credit. I contacted Amazon Customer Service and explained everything to them. At first they tried to tell me that is was the fault of my internet provider, which was hog wash, my other TV worked fine. They wouldn't budge, NO REFUND, NO CREDIT! I was told I could sell the devise to someone. My response was how could I honestly sell something that is defective?Bottom line is that I was left with a $99.00 devise I couldn't use or sell so I decided to cancel my Amazon Prime if this is the way their going treat a long standing customer.

review: I've been an diehard AppleTV fan for a couple of years now. I don't have cable or the tiny satellite dishes, I do get over-the-air (which I'm very happy with). I just recently replaced my old 300 lbs. tv with a new one and figured I'd also get the Amazon Fire TV. It's great! Gary Busey was right the voice search feature is the best! The speed in which this thing returns search results is amazing. The speed that TV shows or movies you want to watch start up is like, FIRE! Pun intended. I really don't think you'll be disappointed in this. Just remember to order an HDMI cable when you order the Amazon Fire TV because it doesn't come with one.
